newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila's Napocor sees gas supply deal by end-Sept.
newsitem.headline: Manila's Napocor sees gas supply deal by end-Sept.

text.p: State-owned National Power Corp (Napocor) said on Tuesday it expected a long-term gas supply deal to be finalised by the end of September, three months ahead of the original end-1997 deadline.
The Napocor's board approved on Tuesday a memorandum of agreement signed with Shell Philippines Exploration BV and Occidental Philippines Inc.
Shell and Occidental are the joint operators of the Camago-Malampaya gas field in southwestern Philippines.
Under the MOU, they will supply Napocor 1,197 petajoules, or about 60 petajoules of gas per year, over the next 20 years starting year 2002.
Napocor president Guido Alfredo Delgado said the board's approval paved the way for a formal negotiation regarding the terms and conditions of the sales agreement.
Earlier, Napocor chairman Francisco Viray said both parties had agreed on a price range of $3.80 to $4.00 per one million BTU (British Terminal Unit) sold.

A Napocor official told reporters the same price range would hold only if Manila Electric Co, the country's biggest power distributor, made a firm commitment that it would buy the electricity produced by the Ilijan power plant of Napocor.
The natural gas is intended to power the 1,200 megawatt Ilijan power plant in northern Philippines.
Shell Philippines is the local drilling unit of Royal Dutch/Shell Group. Oxy is a subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum Corp.
